I get emails from the people who run NaNoWriMo from time to time, and tonight's was an invitation to post the scary things you resolve to do this year.  I decided to yet again make my resolutions public; the more people who know about them will in turn question you about your progress, and it would be embarrassing to say that I haven't done anything so it keeps me on my toes.

So here's what I posted:
1. Run a 10K (as the first step toward running a marathon in the next year or two)
2. Finish my novel
3. Write a play in June 2007 (ScriptFrenzy- from the people who run NaNoWriMo)
4. Successfully complete a Chinese class- I took the first step by registering for one today!
5. Take a management training class (as suggested by the CEO)

I have been on a huge self-improvement kick lately.  I hope it keeps up... the more things I change, the better I feel.  For example, I have been running for the last 4 days.  I am still pretty slow, but I'm keeping it up.  I'm working on building up my distance before I work on speed, although I'm tossing in some interval training in a few weeks, and I am registering for the 10K as soon as it's available.  I am also excited for the Chinese class to pick up (which might happen if I could be bothered to go to Alexandria to buy the textbook...).  And I'm cleaning out my apartment and donating or selling all of the things I don't need anymore.  It's refreshing to get rid of the stuff that just kind of weighs me down.  I'm finding I don't need a whole lot of stuff to be happy.  So if you're in the market for anything, chances are I have it available. ;-)

I wish this weekend were longer... I know it was three days, but the thought of sitting through training tomorrow for eight hours seems exhausting.  And to think I have to do it on Wednesday, too...

On Monday, the very first day of 2007, I went to Capitol Hill for the viewing of President Ford.  It was a bit drizzly when I got there, but the rain cleared up quickly and the wait was just over an hour.  It would have been a shorter wait, but I arrived at the same time that the current President and First Lady arrived and the public wasn't allowed in with them.

I went for two main reasons.  The first reason is simple: I live in Washington, DC, and I like being part of history.  I have been a history student in some way, shape or form for most of my life.  I love knowing that in 60 years I will be able to tell my grandchildren I was part of something that they learned about in history class.  I'm weird that way, I know.

The second reason I went was deeper.  I actually knew very little about President Ford aside from he was never elected to either the Presidency or Vice Presidency (he got both jobs after the resignations of Nixon and Agnew, respectively) and he was criticized and likely lost his own bid for the top office because he pardoned Nixon after Watergate.  I didn't feel the same ties as I did to Reagan, who was president when I was born and- gasp!- some of whose policies I actually agreed with.  For Reagan's viewing I waited for six hours in the sun in a line of more than 60,000.  But I decided to brave the crowds for Ford as well.  Ford wasn't a very well-known or popular president.  A lot of people seemed either uneducated about his life or disinterested.  But here's the thing about people in elected office: they give up a large portion of their lives, they sacrifice their family life, and they exist solely in the public eye to serve their constituents.  That's a really hard, honorable thing to do.  It's not easy to make decisions knowing that the American public's interest and welfare is at stake.  And yet these people offer to do it anyway.  I would agree that many of them want the power and prestige that accompanies an elected office, but there are some that rise to the occasion and want to make a difference.

I don't agree with everything that presidents do- the current one has certainly made a lot of decisions that I entirely disagree with and wish had never been made.  But I appreciate the fact he and all of the past presidents have been willing to serve.  Think of how often smart, capable people don't contribute back to society- think of the number of people you know who couldn't even be bothered to vote during the last election.  Think of the number of people who whine about how bad things are but couldn't be bothered to step up and endorse a candidate or run for themselves.  Think of all of the good ideas entirely wasted because someone isn't motivated enough to write to their Congressman or write a letter to the editor or even share that idea with a friend over coffee.  I don't like politics very much (which is a reason why I majored in Poli Sci- but that's another story).  But I fully respect those who were so fed up with the system they decided to step up and do something about it.

I didn't know much about Ford, and I disagreed with some of the things I do know of that he did.  But I value his contribution as an American who sacrified his time and life with his friends and family to serve the public.  He was a leader in this country.  The least I could do in rememberance and thanks was to stand in line for an hour or so to pay my respects in person.  I met several interesting people in line, and we shared stories about who we were and why we were there as we walked through line.  I got to offer my condolences to his daughter Susan who was standing at the end of the receiving line.  And on the way home I realized that I need to do more in my life to contribute to society.  I have a great life; but I could have a greater life if I did more for others.

I am lucky enough to have the ability to accomplish a lot in my life, but sometimes I look at my accomplishments and feel a burning desire to make a greater impact than I have.  Maybe that's part of being human- but I don't want to be complacent.  I want this year to be about being something more than what I have been.  I wonder how I could ever measure the progress on that goal...

Rest in peace, President Ford.  And thanks for the sudden inspiration.

One of my resolutions is to update this thing more often, so only 12 hours into the new year I am making it happen.  That and I'm still too tired to move from my bed. :)


Was 2006 a good year for you?
2006 was a great year.  Aside from a handful of rocky moments and tough times, I did a complete 180 from where I was a year ago at this time.  I barely know how to begin to improve on how things are right now, but I'm looking forward to trying. :)

What was your favorite moment of the year?
The phone call I got saying I had a job offer back in March!  Immediately after that, I got a second offer which I was able to reject (since the company was horrible), I booked a trip back to Boston and spent the weekend with my mom, and I had dinner with friends in DC.  I felt like I was finally justified in moving back to the District.

What was your least favorite moment of the year?
Probably breaking up with Eric... just because it was the right thing to do didn't make it hurt any less for the first few weeks.

What did you do in 2006 that you had never done before?
I got a real job, I went on my first business trip, and I bought a car- and drove it 8 hours to Boston by myself.  It was a big roadtrip for someone who had never had that kind of freedom before.

Where were you when 2006 began?
At Heather's apartment

Who were you with?
Heather, John and Kaiti

Where will you be when 2006 ends?
I spent the evening at the Grand Hyatt in DC being very drunk and very happy and wearing a fabulous green dress.

Who will you be with when 2006 ends?
Jamie, Megan, Christina, Danielle, Catherine, and assorted friends and boyfriends.

Did you keep your new years resolution of 2005?
I didn't make any last year.  In 2005 I jokingly said my resolutions were to find a job and not get myself killed, and when I didn't come close to achieving the first one and barely kept the second one I decided resolutions were a bad idea.  I have changed my mind a bit now.

Do you have a new years resolution for 2007?
1. Run a 10K in the spring (I'm shooting for the Capitol Hill Classic in May), and if I like running enough I want to tackle a half marathon in the fall
2. Join a kickball team (hey, I heard the DC league is fun!)
3. Create and maintain a more detailed budget
4. Make better food choices: less junk food, more veggies.  Along those lines, I think I am going to be a vegetarian once a week- I could stand to cut back on red meat.
5. Write more often.
  5a: Update this journal more often and blog about real topics
  5b: Finish my NaNoWriMo book; participate in the playwriting version of NaNoWriMo in June

Did you fall in love in 2006?
No, I guess not.

If yes, with who?
--

If yes, do they know?
--

Are you still in love with them?
I actually fell out of love this year...

Do you regret it?
--

Did you break-up with anyone in 2006?
Yes.  I think we're trying to be friends now, but admittedly I'm not very good at this particular phase.

Did you make any new friends in 2006?
Yes!  In fact, I met some of my best friends this year.

Who are your favorite new friends?
I really don't play favorites when it comes to friends, but I will say the girls I spent New Years with are some of the most fantastic people I have ever met.

What was your favorite month of 2006?
February was pretty good all around.

Did you travel outside of the USA in 2006?
Nope.  I had hoped to go to the Caribbean, but Eric was always too busy.  2007 has to be a travel year... I feel the need to see the world again.

How many different states did you travel to in 2006?
Ummm... Maine, Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, Maryland, Florida, Nevada.  I traveled through a bunch of others as well.

Did you lose anybody close to you in 2006?
My grandfather passed away in August.  Aside from that, we were lucky not to lose anyone this year.

Did you miss anybody in the past year?
I miss people all the time.  It's part of my nature... I miss everyone when they aren't with me.

What was your favorite movie that you saw in 2006?
The Holiday was a great movie.  And I won't lie... Clerks 2 was pretty great.

What was your favorite song from 2006?
"Chasing Cars" by Snow Patrol.  Totally love that song.

What was your favorite record(s) from 2006?:
I really didn't buy many CDs this year, and the ones I did buy weren't particularly new... but The Fray's CD was great.

How many concerts did you see in 2006?
Not many... Journey and Def Leppard in July, John Mayer and Sheryl Crow in September, The Reflex a bunch of times, and a handful of smaller club shows. 

Did you have a favorite concert in 2006?
Journey and Sheryl Crow were both great... and I ran into people I hadn't seen in a long time at both of them!

Did you drink a lot of alcohol in 2006?
Danielle actually had the best answer to this: in the final moments of 2006, as we were getting ready to go to the Hyatt, she said to everyone, "I could drink all of you under the table... everyone except Steph anyway."

Did you do a lot of drugs in 2006?
I have never done any drugs.  Absolutely not my scene.

How many people did you love in 2006?
I love many people... in terms of romance, I loved one person, but in terms of warm fuzzy love, I love too many people to count.

Did you do anything you are ashamed of this year?
Ehhh... a few.  But I can't change the past, and I don't dwell in it.

What was the worst lie someone told you in 2006?
I'm not sure I should post that on the internet.

Did you treat somebody badly in 2006?
Yes... I wasn't nice to Eric in the end.  I should have treated him better, and I apologized, but I still feel sorry about it.

What was the best thing you bought in 2006?
Plymouth the bunny and my car!

Did somebody treat you badly in 2006?
A few... Eric especially, but break ups tend to bring out the worst in people.  That's pretty much why people break up though.

How much money did you spend in 2006?
I don't even want to think about what that number might be.

What was your proudest moment of 2006?
Definitely at the end of the year when I was in my goal review session at work and the CEO said I am constantly reminding him why he hired me in the first place.  That was a great compliment.  And my parents both told me they are proud of me at Christmas, and knowing I have their approval makes me happy.

If you could go back in time to any moment of 2006?
I wouldn't.  The memories are so good I wouldn't want to relive them or recreate them- just remember them.

What are your plans for 2007?
Move to a townhouse, travel, keep up the resolutions, and enjoy every moment of this fabulous life I get to lead.

Quote a song lyric that sums up your year:
Same one I always pick- from "Pretty Good Year" by Tori Amos
They say you were something in those formative years
Hold on to nothing as fast as you can
Still... pretty good year

I was watching the end of the Michican/Ohio State game, and one of the announcers says:

If Notre Dame upsets USC tonight, and if USC wins that game, that's going to be a great game.

WHAT?!?!?

What does that even mean?  If both teams win?  No matter which team wins?  And then it hits me- I thought Notre Dame defeated Army today.  So I check the scoreboard, and sure enough: Notre Dame 41, Army 9.

Do I even need to go on about how much was wrong with that statement?  Wow.  Just wow.  I know very little about college football (save for Clemson, FSU, Florida State, and WVU- and each of those is by proxy, particularly since CMU wasn't known for its football team), but even I could come up with something more intelligible to say on national television.

This is why I don't like most sports announcers.  I like Don and Remy... but I think NESN trumps all sports channels.  I am getting DirecTV in my next house/apartment just so I can order the sports package that will give me NESN.  Don and Remy are hilarious, and they don't say anything stupid.  They know the Sox, and they don't make these weird, overarching comments about outcomes and possibilities.  I appreciate how they keep some kind of integrity in their choice of words.  Watching football can drive me crazy.  Watching most baseball games kills brain cells.  I still don't get how so many people watch Nascar week after week.  (Actually, to prove my point, I turned on the Nascar Busch race just to get the first quote I could.  It was, "All of these teams want one thing: a victory.  This is the first lap."  No way, seriously??  I thought the numbers in the corner that say Lap 1 of 200 were just suggestions.)

I really am losing my tolerance for stupidity.

I'm coming down with a cold.  I can feel it in the back of my head, behind my nose and in my eyes.  I hate this feeling.  I have spent the morning sipping tea and eating those Cold-Eeze zinc tablets like it's in my job description.  And my whole body is achy.  My arms are achy, my toes are achy, and my head is especially achy.  This would be a great day to go home early, put in a movie, and sleep until tomorrow.  Instead, I'm going to wait it out and hope I feel better after lunch.  I'm sincerely doubting it, but it's worth a shot.  Besides, my sick days roll over to next year, and I want to know I have a few waiting for me if need be. 

The better news is that one week from today I am driving home for Thanksgiving.  Granted, the road trip itself could be the longest 10 hours I will ever spend trapped in a car (save the 10 hours it will take to get back here on Sunday), but I'm going to make the best out of a potentially bad situation.  I would almost rather drive it by myself (with PK- he will be an adorable little co-pilot), but on the other hand it might be more enjoyable than I am preparing myself for.  I just feel very uneasy.  I don't like feeling anything other than happy, which is were I usually balance out.  Thanksgiving Day also has some potential to be, oh, less than ideal... I'm not exactly thrilled with how it has all played out.  But I had nothing to do with the decisions that were made, so my job is only to deal with the results and try to keep smiling.  This will be an interesting challenge.  I'm bringing just about every CD I can carry just in case. 

Ugh.  Too much negative energy. 

I'm very much looking forward to New Years Eve.  I'm looking forward to another fresh start.  Saying goodbye to 2005 was a huge relief and a really exciting moment (even though nothing actually changed- just because a new year starts doesn't automatically wipe our slates clean).  Saying goodbye to 2006 will be bittersweet, though.  2006 was absolutely the defining year I wanted.  A new job, a new chance in DC, a fantastic group of new friends, and the strengthening of some older friendships.  I also said my share of goodbyes, some more permanent than others, and some still yet to be defined.  And although there is still a lot of time left in 2006, I'm starting to prepare for what is to come.  I'm already reflecting on what was and getting excited about what is to come.  I used to plan my years according to how I wanted them to go and change my priorities as things panned out.  I won't make that mistake again.  That is a New Years resolution I made early this time around. 

My novel writing has actually been going really well this month.  For the first year it's almost week 3 and I still think this piece of crap has some literary potential.  And I love all of the characters.  All of them mean something to me this time.  I'm still pretty serious that I'm going on Oprah's Book Club sooner rather than later. :) 

If I could put half as much energy into researching the cost of case binding as I did into this blog I would be a much happier camper.  Although not as happy as I would be if my cold medicine would kick in and make me feel better than groggy...

I know that the longer I stay in DC the more attached I will become and the harder it will be for me to ever leave.  And the longer I stay the more cyncial and jaded I will become as well- DC is a fabulous place to be young, but a difficult place to grow old.  This isn't a great place to raise a family and have a routine.  There are better, more stable places for that elsewhere.  But the more I think about it, the less I want to grow old and have a routine.  I love being spontaneous, going out without plans and having everything be a little adventure.  I spent years planning every part of my life, and one by one the plans fell through and made way for even better things.  I am a million miles away from everything I thought I would have and want a few years ago: the only thing that never changed was DC.  I knew it would be home, and I made it exactly that.  My friends are like family, and so much of my family is here.  I am happy running around Dupont at 2 AM and hoping to make the train by 3.  I have my local haunts like Mai Thai and Vermillion and Front Page, and I can tell anyone how to get anywhere on the metro.  I know where to sit on the yellow line so that between Pentagon and L'Enfant I can see the Washington Monument and the Jefferson Memorial.  I am involved in my community, I have a great job, and I'm the happiest I have ever been.  If there is a catch to all of this, I haven't found it yet.

Even I find my optimism a bit nauseating.  But it beats the alternative.  And the thought of giving this up makes me appreciate that I have it at all.  Nothing lasts forever, but you can't change the past and no matter what now my past was here.

In honor of my love for DC, Christina and I are going to the Capitals game tonight.  I haven't been to a hockey game since Pittsburgh.  And BNL is singing the national anthem.  I'm so excited I'm leaving work at 3:30 since I can't handle sitting here any longer anyway. :)

Today I actually got a political flyer in my mailbox instead of the usual collection of bills and credit card applications.  It was kind of surprising, actually, because in all of the time I have lived in this hotbead of political lunatics I have never had anything directly sent to me.  But it got me kind of excited, too- I get to vote as a Virginia resident for the first time next week.  And elections here are pretty intense- Allen vs. Webb, the gay marriage ammendment... I like voting.  I like being heard.  Probably not a surprise for anyone who knows me, but I like contributing to something bigger than myself.  I like voting because the government and this country is bigger than me, and lending my voice to it reminds me that my contribution is important and necessary.  I know I am probably the last person left on this planet who believes voting can make you heard, but I do.  I believe it.  And it makes me happy to think that.

Bottom line: vote!

In additional exciting news, I spent most of my morning chatting with the CEO's executive assistant.  She has an extensive background in theatre, and I can listen to her talk all the time.  She likes to tell people that we're so similar because of our theatre connection and because we think the same way, which I love.  She told me today that she is working for the Kennedy Center and for one of the DC opera houses; then she told me that every once and a while they need production assistants and if I am interested she will recommend me for one.

If I could be a production assistant for the Kennedy Center my entire life would probably be complete.  There would be no need to try anything else; I would have accomplished just about everything I ever dreamed about.

On the other hand, I will continue to plug away at the daily grind... partially because I'm still very excited about the China trips, and partially because in a few weeks the company is giving me my very own office.  And it will have filing cabinets and a big L-shaped desk and bookshelves, and there will be a door that I can close when I decide to eat lunch or want a few moments to myself.

I think the door is more important to me than even I know.  The COO told me about the office yesterday, and I said, "Really?  With a door that opens and closes?"  He probably thinks I'm insane.  I think he's a great guy, and for some reason I can't manage coherent sentences when he is around.  Thank goodness he is forgiving when it comes to me being a total moron.

I have also been considering going to church.  This was a weird conclusion to come to because I have never gone to church on any kind of regular basis.  But in the last month I have been in two of them, and I have emerged both times with a strange sense of peace.  Anyone who knows me well (that means you, Josh) knows how absolutely out of left field this comment is.  And it might not pan out; but it might, and I think I owe it to myself to explore this as a possibility.  I have come to a spiritual crossroads of sorts.  Perhaps it's time to start taking other avenues to understand what is going on in my life.

It's National Novel Writing Month, and I'm working on another book.  This year is different though: it's day one and I don't hate the novel at all.  I think it's going to turn out really well.  And I still think my topic is pretty good.  I'm optimistic that this time next year Oprah will be introducing it as her next book club selection.

This is about as disjointed an entry as I can write.  My mind is all over the place.  But it's a nice feeling since all of the thoughts are good, and I am in a good place.

What can I say?  When you're on, you're on.

I found an amazing job.

And more amazing than the job itself is the fact they offered the position to me.

The worst is over, the bright light at the end of the tunnel is right in front of me, and I've taken my first step into what promises to me a great and exciting future.

And now I'll start from the beginning.

For those of you who don't know, or haven't put it all together yet, I'm back in DC. I woke up one morning in January and realized I wanted more than anything in the world my second chance at success. My first chance was interrupted by forces I couldn't predict or control, and I wanted to bury it in the past where it belongs. I found a place online where I could rent a room on a month-to-month basis while I tested the waters, and I packed my suitcase and moved in on President's Day. The house is beautiful and in a safe neighborhood close to the metro. I have my own room, free use of the kitchen and living room, and there is a cute cat to play with when I'm here. Last Monday I applied to two jobs. On Tuesday I got an email and scheduled an interview for Thursday. I also got a phone call from my roommate with a temp position offer while I was looking for work. On Wednesday, I went to her office. As I was leaving on Wednesday I got a phone call from the staffing agency that was handling the second job and set up an interview for Monday morning. On Thursday I interviewed with a company in Arlington for an Associate Producer position on a government affairs team. The interview went really well, although it sounded like a ton of responsibility and a lot of potential for failure. I was not as thrilled with it as I wanted to be. When I got home there was a "takehome interview" section waiting in my inbox. It took four hours to do- it was all research and conference planning on a topic I knew nothing about. I was a little put off by that, and I was a little wary of the position again. On Friday I went to work again, and then it was the weekend.

Side note: I had an amazing night on Friday. I went to see The Vagina Monologues at American University with a whole group of girls from the DC area. We had an awesome time, and it was great to meet some new people! And they are wicked active in DC, so I'm looking forward to spending lots of time at happy hours and events from now on! 


A bunch of us after the show!

On Monday I went to the staffing agency at 10:30. I had to do 2 hours of computer and typing tests, and then I sat and waited for the results for 15 minutes. When I got called into my analysis interview the woman told me I scored in a advanced level for everything (big surprise- I went to CMU!), and she said she wanted to discuss a new opportunity with me. She pulled in the client manager for the company, and that woman told me about a job working in homeland and international security in Old Town Alexandria. It sounded interesting and I said I would interview for it. I left the agency at 1:30, at 2:30 I had a call from the woman again, and by 3:30 I was in Old Town for an interview. That lasted for a little more than an hour, and I had two separate interviews with two people from the company- the COO and the manager of the department. After about 10 minutes the COO started telling me all about the company's finances and what great shape they were in (when companies start divulging that information it's usually a good sign that they want to to feel comfortable there). The manager was harder to read, but she smiled a lot and seemed impressed by my resume and everything I had done over the last 5 years. I left there at 5:00, and at 9:00 the next morning I had an offer from them which I gladly accepted.

About the job: I am the Education Coordinator for the company, and my role is to facilitate conferences and workshops while also managing talent, PR, and customer relations. It's not entry level at all, and the issues are really interesting- my dad actually works with some of them! The pay is much more than I thought it would be, and the benefits are amazing (severe bragging ahead): 100% company paid health, dental, and vision care (nothing comes out of my paycheck!), free parking, 401K, 5 sick days, 12 paid holidays, and 30 vacation days!!! That's six whole weeks!!! The staff is fairly young and energetic, the building is beautiful, and they said it won't be too long before I have an office instead of a cubicle. The downside is it's a temp position for about a month or two since it was through the agency, but I was assured it will be full-time very quickly because they told the staffing agency their intentions are to groom me for the manager position so they can promote the woman who has it right now. I'm still in a complete state of shock, but it's a happy feeling.

Right after I accepted the job, I got a call from the people at CYLC- where I was supposed to work starting last summer- and they offered me a job. I told them the current situation, and they said if in the next month or so I don't like it at the new company they will gladly welcome me back! And then this morning I got a call from the company in Arlington who also made me an offer, but I got to go with my gut instinct and (politely) reject it.

And that's where things stand. Employed, in a safe place, and I'm going back to Boston this weekend to celebrate!

So thanks to everyone who has been so supportive and for keeping me positive, and a big thank you to everyone who celebrated with me on the phone and on AIM last night- and the celebrating will continue for a while! The next step is apartment hunting! If there is a secure building with an updated kitchen in a nice neighborhood, I am going to find it!

For now, it's time to get some packing done and get ready to head out in a few hours- tonight I'm having drinks in Dupont and dinner in Georgetown with some of the girls. Perfect way to celebrate the middle of an awesome week. :-)

A great job, a cute apartment in a safe neighborhood, a house in Florida, a graduate degree, life with my wonderful boyfriend, a puppy of our own. I haven't thought of the future as a place with possibilities and hope in a long time. That's how I know I'm better now.

I IM Kaiti because she gets my sense of humor, and she's there for me around the clock. I email Nancy and find more support and friendship from her than I ever would have expected from a former employer. I call people and email people at random now, just because I'm thinking of them. Every day I see the pictures I brought from home. A picture of my house, pictures of friends and family, pictures from high school and college. I look at them when I feel lonely and it connects me again. I look at them when I'm happy and I'm grateful for what once was, for it shaped my life. I look at them when I'm falling asleep and I know that somewhere in my mind I'm safe and sound. That's how I know I'll never forget where I come from.

I feel like after the last few weeks, I could write a lengthy commentary about how to find an apartment in DC.  I don't think I'll publish one until I have moved in somewhere and have successfully lasted more than two months, but for the time being I'm making a list of things I have learned.  Those of you who have plans to live in DC at some point, take notice.  Those of you who live or have lived in DC, feel free to contribute!

  1. No one, and I mean NO ONE should have to pay $1800 for a one bedroom apartment in a reasonably safe part of NW.  That's insane.  I don't care what the "market price" says.  If the "market price" dictated that you also drink a quart of turpentine before listing your property, would you do that too?
  2. Worse than paying $1800 in NW, no one should have to pay $1800 for Bethesda, Arlington, or Alexandria.  That's suburbia.  Suburbia should have to pay less because they pay more to commute.
  3. If the listing says "Historic Northwest" anywhere in it, keep looking.  "Historic Northwest" means Eckington, Shaw, Ledroit Park, and a variety of other shady places somewhere on the green line or the wrong side of the red line.  It's only affordable because no one else will live there.
  4. Herndon, Springfield, Tyson's Corner, and Baltimore are not, and will never be, "just minutes from downtown."  Those minutes will actually show up in large clumps called hours.
  5. If it says "gated community," don't live there.  Gates keep crime out in the suburbs, but they keep crime inside in the city.  Secured access is always beneficial, however.
  6. If the word "cozy" comes up, you can strike that housing option as well.  "Cozy" means no more than 450 sq. feet.  Do you really want to live in a dorm room and pay $1500 a month to do so?
  7. There really isn't such a thing as a "sunny basement apartment."  I've visited them.  It's hard to have a "sunny basement apartment" when there aren't any windows.
  8. If you have to list your apartment several times, change the wording a little so it's not noticeable.  Those of us who frequently scan the apartments-for-rent pages aren't going to consider a unit that everyone else has been rejecting for weeks.  Either conceal the fact you can't find a renter or lower your asking price.
  9. Anacostia is a scary, scary place.  Don't even pretend to think about it.
  10. And this is a big one: I don't care if the place has marble floors, granite countertops, custom cabinets, and your own parking space.  Studio apartments are not worth $3000.  If you have $3000 to spend on that apartment, you can afford to get into the DC real estate market.  Then you can buy your own space, move out, and charge someone else and exorbitant amount in rent.

I feel better now.

Every once and a while I run into someone who, in a very quiet way, completely changes my outlook on everything.

The first time this happened was in high school.  My dad and I were eating lunch in Hyannis at a Burger King right after I taught two hour-long sessions on effective communication skills for the Massachusetts Association of Student Councils annual conference.  I was exhausted, my voice was going, and I was a little nervous about the reviews since they were going to tie into how our student council was accredited for the next year.  We were eating our sandwiches, and I noticed one of the guys working there.  He was probably in his 70s, old enough to have retired by then.  He was washing the tables in the back corner, and he was smiling while he worked.  I felt like my heart was going to break while I watched him.  I wondered why he had to work when he should be sitting on a beach in Florida.  I hoped he had a nice family to go home to.  I hope he had a nice life, and we was smiling because he was thinking about it.

Tonight, my mom and I were buying fabric so she can make a tablecloth for a breakfast she's hosting in a few weeks.  The man who was cutting the fabric clearly had a disability of some sort- he had trouble enunciating his words, and we had trouble following what he was saying.  He wanted to know what I was going to make with the yarn I was buying (a puppy), and then he wanted to know if I was going to make it look like a real puppy with a collar and tags.  I told him yes, I was, and told us all about his sister's puppy and how she make it wear sweaters and how he thinks the puppy is humiliated by them.  I hope he has a nice home to go to.  I hope his family is wonderful to him, and I hope he is happy.

I feel like those of us who are most fortunate in this life- the ones who are smart, well-educated, and ambitious enough to take the world by storm- are the ones who are the most unhappy.  I know so many people who I graduated with, or those who have graduated recently, who are so miserable with where they are in life.  Many days out of the week I count myself among them.  But the people we feel sorry for or sometimes ignore completely are the ones who find satisfaction and a place on this planet.  I hope we all find that kind of happiness someday, or at the very least some kind of perspective.  It's something I really want to work on from now on.  When the day is done, in spite of everything that bothers me in this world, I'm OK.  We all are.
